Title: b'For your retirement planning, count on living until age 95'
Text:
b'CLOSE According to a study by the Employee Benefit Research Institute, 65.4% of American families with heads of household 55 and older held debt in 2013. USA TODAY

Planning for how long your nest egg needs to last is a difficult one. (Photo: Thinkstock)

If you knew your date of death, retirement planning would be a breeze.

Unfortunately \xe2\x80\x94 or maybe fortunately? \xe2\x80\x94 you don't. And that can make planning for retirement extremely difficult. Does your nest egg need to last 20 years? 30 years? 40 years? And what about couples? How should couples go about planning for the likelihood that one spouse \xe2\x80\x94 usually the husband \xe2\x80\x94 predeceases the other?

Well, if you\xe2\x80\x99re like most people, you\xe2\x80\x99re guessing at this, and guessing quite wrong.

\xe2\x80\x9cMany people do not understand longevity well, and those people who plan often do not plan for long enough,\xe2\x80\x9d says Anna Rappaport, president of a retirement consulting firm bearing her name and chair of the Society of Actuaries (SOA) Committee on Post-Retirement Needs and Risks.

Noel Abkemeier is the founder of Abkemeier Actuarial and chair of the American Academy of Actuaries Lifetime Income Task Force. (Photo: Handout)

Becoming familiar with current life-expectancy statistics is the first order of business. \xe2\x80\x9cThere are two aspects to addressing longevity,\xe2\x80\x9d says Noel Abkemeier, the founder of Abkemeier Actuarial and chair of the American Academy of Actuaries Lifetime Income Task Force. \xe2\x80\x9cFirst, understanding it, and then planning an income that will last throughout life.\xe2\x80\x9d

You may live much longer than you think. "There have been significant improvements in how long people survive in retirement, especially for wealthier Americans,\xe2\x80\x9d says David Blanchett, head of retirement research at Morningstar Investment Management.

Consider: Someone born in 1950 was expected to live to age 68.2. By contrast, someone born in 2014 was expected to live to age 78.8, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. In other words, someone born today will need to fund an extra 10 years of retirement vs. someone born 66 years ago.

What\xe2\x80\x99s more, life expectancy for those alive at age 65 has also increased dramatically. In 1950, a 65-year-old male could expect to live another 12.8 years. In 2014, a 65-year-old male could expect to live on average of 18 more years. The same is true for women. In 1950, a 65-year-o woman could expect to live another 15 years. By 2014, a 65-year-old woman could expect to live another 20.5 years.

The Actuaries Longevity Illustrator can give you a good sense of how long you might live. Another resource is the Living to 100 life expectancy calculator.

Financial advisers are starting to change assumptions about how long clients will live to make sure they don't outlive savings, according to a survey by InvestmentNews. Advisers are basing retirement-income plans on an average life span of 91 for men and 94 for women, according to the survey.

\xe2\x80\x9cMany people do not understand longevity well,\xe2\x80\x9d says Anna Rappaport, chair of the Society of Actuaries (SOA) Committee on Post-Retirement Needs and Risks. (Photo: Anna Rappaport Consulting)

Consider the probabilities. One drawback with using life expectancy to plan for retirement is that it\xe2\x80\x99s just an average. One-half will die before life expectancy, and the other half after. So, the better way to approach the problem is to consider the probability of living to certain ages.

Consider: There\xe2\x80\x99s a 25% chance that a 65-year-old man will live to 93; a 25% chance that a 65-year-old woman will live to 96; and for a couple 65 years old, there\xe2\x80\x99s a 25% chance that the surviving spouse lives to 98, according to SOA projections.

All that said, Blanchett still thinks it makes more sense for people (and planners) to use a fixed time horizon, such as planning to age 95.

Couples should consider their combined planning timeline. For couples who are 65 today, there\xe2\x80\x99s a 45% chance that a wife outlives her husband by five years and a 20% chance by 15 years, according to the SOA. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t forget that assets need to last until the second to die for couples,\xe2\x80\x9d says Rappaport.

Consider your genes and behavior. \xe2\x80\x9cSome factors that influence how long you live may be beyond your control,\xe2\x80\x9d according to the SOA. \xe2\x80\x9cOthers depend upon the choices you make every day. A successful retirement plan will address both.\xe2\x80\x9d

How will you manage longevity risk? There are some time-honored ways to deal with the risk of outliving your assets. Those include the use of annuities, a sound asset-drawdown plan, delaying Social Security to age 70 for the higher wage earner, and a reverse mortgage. Read Managing Post-Retirement Risks - A Guide to Retirement Planning.

Remember, says Abkemeier, half of retirees will live longer (than life expectancy) and, to build in a cushion, individuals should plan for an additional five or more years when considering lifetime income.

Robert Powell is editor of Retirement Weekly, contributes regularly to USA TODAY, The Wall Street Journal and MarketWatch. Got questions about money? Email Bob at rpowell@allthingsretirement.com.

Title: b'Katy Waldman\xe2\x80\x99s 10 Favorite Books of 2016'
Text:
b'Photo illustration by Slate. Images by Amazon

* * *

Advertisement



Traister was an indispensable voice during the 2016 election, writing about Hillary Clinton with warmth, lucidity, and insight. All three qualities are on display in her extraordinarily researched, cogently argued investigation into the rise of the single woman, which examines how unmarried women have long spearheaded social change and tracks the uneven line from past progressive movements to our current feminist flourishing. (I only wish she could have included a post-Trump addendum.) Especially notable is Traister\xe2\x80\x99s attention to the full racial and economic spectrum of womanhood and to the oft-underrated bonds of female friendship.

Heat and Light by Jennifer Haigh. Ecco.

In this sensitive and sweeping novel, Haigh returns to the fictional Bakerton, a mining village overtaken by \xe2\x80\x9cfracking frenzy\xe2\x80\x9d in the late 2010s. The locals are divided over whether to lease their land to an unscrupulous energy company; transient drillers flood into the bars with their lusts and sorrows; activists descend; salesmen make bargains with the townsfolk, the devil, and themselves. By the end of the book\xe2\x80\x99s 430 pages, Haigh\xe2\x80\x99s patient, cumulative arguments (about greed, faith, chance, and community) have achieved real sonority, and we feel fully invested in her individual characters. Heat and Light is that rare \xe2\x80\x9cambitious social novel\xe2\x80\x9d whose interlocking pieces are as vividly and precisely realized as its panoramic themes.

Advertisement



Modern Lovers by Emma Straub. Riverhead.

Read Slate\xe2\x80\x99s review.

As she demonstrated with her witty The Vacationers, Straub has charm to spare. In Modern Lovers, an ensemble novel about more-or-less forlorn fortysomethings in twee Brooklyn, her trademark nimbleness serves a story of startling emotional depth. Straub\xe2\x80\x99s adult characters (some of whom played together in a punk band) can\xe2\x80\x99t quite relinquish the dream of youth; their children don\xe2\x80\x99t know how to grow up, either. Disruptions small and large break across their interconnected paths, and there is deep satisfaction in watching an author as psychologically astute and empathetic as Straub play out their various responses. But the purest joys of the novel come from rooting for these relatably rudderless people as they attempt to sail into maturity with a modicum of grace.

Moonglow by Michael Chabon. Harper.

Read Slate\xe2\x80\x99s review.

Again, you may be shocked\xe2\x80\x94shocked!\xe2\x80\x94to learn that the latest novel from Pulitzer Prize\xe2\x80\x93winning author Chabon, a shimmering \xe2\x80\x9cmemoir\xe2\x80\x9d about his grandparents, is among the year\xe2\x80\x99s best. But the pleasure of surrendering to Chabon\xe2\x80\x99s remarkable skills as a storyteller can\xe2\x80\x99t be overstated. He excels on every level: his gorgeous, funny, looping sentences; his knack for the harlequin escapade; his deft swerves into emotional honesty and power; his intuitive mastery of suspense, tension, and release. Plus, American hero Ramon the cat deserves all the accolades for his third-act moment of bravery. Go Ramon!

Advertisement



My Name Is Lucy Barton by Elizabeth Strout. Random House.

In Strout\xe2\x80\x99s deceptively quiet hands, a line of dialogue can seem simple or commonplace until it begins to burn, a glowing coal plucked from the furnace of some character\xe2\x80\x99s psyche. My Name Is Lucy Barton is a masterpiece of slow-dawning meaning, an interrogation of family relationships that takes as its occasion an older woman\xe2\x80\x99s visit to the bedside of her convalescent daughter. (And that\xe2\x80\x99s all I\xe2\x80\x99m going to say about the plot!)

Night of the Animals by Bill Broun. Ecco.

In the England of 2052, an authoritarian king lords over a broken, drug-addled society, while the internet plays directly on people\xe2\x80\x99s corneas and suicide cultists seek salvation in the murder of animals. Homeless, nonagenarian addict Cuthbert believes he can save the world by releasing the creatures in the London Zoo, a task that plunges him deep into Celtic myth, the intrigues of the dystopian police state, and the scattered phantasms of his buried past. Broun\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cBrexit novel,\xe2\x80\x9d acquiring new resonance under the sign of Trump, is an eerie, wildly original debut\xe2\x80\x94a blur of beauty and madness, like van Gogh\xe2\x80\x99s Starry Night.

This novel\xe2\x80\x94about an academic malcontent; his accidentally revolutionary mother; and the constellation of students, family members, blowhard politicians, reactionary cops, video game addicts, ghosts, and Norwegian hobgoblins encircling them\xe2\x80\x94is a Thanksgiving banquet of a book, a narrative table groaning with dishes both delicious and overdone. Hill, a gifted satirist whose lambasting of special-snowflake millennials and escapist gamer nerds can feel too broad, slips in tone from intelligent and realist to zanily experimental to lush and dreamy. His 600-page opus is an extravaganza of talent, a beautiful and idiosyncratic mess that for all its flashiness finds its most expressive voice when exploring basic human themes: love, anger, loneliness, regret.

In Winters\xe2\x80\x99 speculative portrait of present-day America, slavery persists in four states (the \xe2\x80\x9cHard Four\xe2\x80\x9d), and hypercompetent government agents track down fugitives with the amoral aplomb of James Bond. One such operative is Victor, a freed slave whose nightmarish past keeps erupting into his detective work. The book is profligate with its noir tropes, funny, gripping, imaginative, and inexorable as it gradually unmasks the unthinkable evil at its core. The storyline, in other words, doubles as a descent\xe2\x80\x94and there is always further down to go.

Advertisement



Whitehead, who won this year\xe2\x80\x99s National Book Award for fiction, isn\xe2\x80\x99t hurting for laurels\xe2\x80\x94and yet it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to imagine drafting a list of 2016\xe2\x80\x99s mightiest books without including this phantasmagorical slash into the dark gut of American racism. Cora, an escaped slave, travels through the South on a literal subterranean train, each stop an object lesson in a different ghoulish facet of white supremacy. Her resolve and dignity are moving\xe2\x80\x94but it\xe2\x80\x99s the author\xe2\x80\x99s playfulness and unpredictability that elevate this traditional tale of hardship into something singular, fugitive, and strange.

This memoir, from a literary-minded neurosurgeon who is diagnosed with terminal bone cancer in his 30s, is poetic and generous, intimate and profound. In clear and flowing prose, Kalanithi describes his self-formation as a doctor and then the evaporation of that identity as he becomes, again, a patient, starving for time. If some sections of the book are rougher or more abstract than others, the overall work recalls a world of almost pre-Christian luminousness, in which classical concepts like virtue, honor, and excellence still have purchase, chance or fate reigns supreme, and no person can evade the dark forever.

Title: b'Why Glenn Beck Really Hates Steve Bannon'
Text:
b"There has been something delightfully ironic about watching Glenn Beck become one of the sanest voices in conservative media over this past year.

The Texas-based right-wing radio host and founder of The Blaze website\xe2\x80\x94who once declared that Barack Obama has a \xe2\x80\x9cdeep-seated hatred for white people\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94was #NeverTrump from the beginning of the GOP primaries. He initially threw his weight behind Ted Cruz and didn\xe2\x80\x99t budge from his anti-Trump stance even after Cruz decided to endorse the man who insulted his wife and blamed his father for the JFK assassination.

As Election Day approached, Beck openly toyed with the idea of voting for Hillary Clinton, criticized Trump during the third presidential debate for his baffling incoherence on abortion, and called FBI Director James Comey \xe2\x80\x9cirresponsible\xe2\x80\x9d for tossing an October grenade into the race at the last minute.

Throughout the race, however, Beck has reserved his harshest words for Steve Bannon, who just this weekend was named President-elect Trump\xe2\x80\x99s chief strategist. But is Beck\xe2\x80\x99s great moral outrage over the self-proclaimed leader of the alt-right as selfless as it seems? Or is it personal?

It was all the way back in February of this year, when Cruz still had a chance and months before Trump had hired Bannon to serve as his campaign CEO, that Beck launched his attack.

\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m telling you that I believe that Bannon thinks he\xe2\x80\x99s either going to be the chief of staff or he\xe2\x80\x99s going to be the next Roger Ailes,\xe2\x80\x9d Beck said, presciently. He accused the Breitbart executive chairman of \xe2\x80\x9ctaking orders from a political candidate\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9creworking your entire site to promote the lies of a specific candidate without any kind of truth behind these things.\xe2\x80\x9d In Beck\xe2\x80\x99s view, that made Bannon more like Joseph Goebbels than Ailes.

\xe2\x80\x9cAndrew Breitbart would be spinning in his grave right now,\xe2\x80\x9d Beck said, referring to the late founder of Breitbart.com.

But as it turns out, neither Breitbart nor Bannon were big fans of Beck, who launched The Blaze as a direct competitor to Breitbart after he was let go by Ailes and Fox News.

A few months after Beck started broadcasting his GBTV show online in 2011, Andrew Breitbart went on Steve Bannon\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cVictory Sessions\xe2\x80\x9d podcast, and the two men spent a good deal of time trashing their new competition.

Beck had made some provocative comments comparing Newt Gingrich to Barack Obama and suggested Tea Partiers only liked Gingrich because he was white, and Breitbart and Bannon accused Beck of \xe2\x80\x9crace-baiting.\xe2\x80\x9d

\xe2\x80\x9cIn the past, Beck has made a lot of mistakes, and his supporters come out and try to defend him, because Beck is a coward and will not defend himself when he makes a mistake or lies about a person or steals content,\xe2\x80\x9d Breitbart said.

Egging him on, Bannon replied, \xe2\x80\x9cHold on, I want to go back over this: You\xe2\x80\x99re saying that Glenn Beck\xe2\x80\x99s a coward, Glenn Beck\xe2\x80\x99s a liar, and you\xe2\x80\x99re saying that Glenn Beck steals material from people?\xe2\x80\x9d

We will not share your email with anyone for any reason.

\xe2\x80\x9cOh yes, and this is well-documented,\xe2\x80\x9d Breitbart said, laying out what he viewed as Beck\xe2\x80\x99s deliberately misleading coverage of the Shirley Sherrod scandal, which began its life on Breitbart\xe2\x80\x99s Big Government website. He went on to say that Beck has been known to \xe2\x80\x9ctake countless bloggers\xe2\x80\x99 content, to turn it into book gold, to turn it into chalkboard gold, his infamous chalkboards,\xe2\x80\x9d an allegation explored in detail by The Daily Caller\xe2\x80\x99s Matthew Boyle earlier that year.

Asked by Bannon what he would like to see Beck do next, Breitbart said, \xe2\x80\x9cAt this point, I don\xe2\x80\x99t care what he does because he\xe2\x80\x99s dead to me.\xe2\x80\x9d

Five years later, Bannon had officially joined the Trump campaign and Beck was openly calling him \xe2\x80\x9cquite possibly the most dangerous guy in all of American politics\xe2\x80\x9d and a \xe2\x80\x9chorrible, despicable human being.\xe2\x80\x9d His assertion that Bannon uses the \xe2\x80\x9cDark Web\xe2\x80\x9d to exact revenge on his enemies landed Beck on Breitbart\xe2\x80\x99s list of the \xe2\x80\x9c six dumbest claims \xe2\x80\x9d journalists made about Bannon.

After news broke that Bannon would be joining Trump in the White House, Beck once again warned against Bannon\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cclear tie to white nationalists,\xe2\x80\x9d adding, \xe2\x80\x9cHe\xe2\x80\x99s a terrifying man.\xe2\x80\x9d

These sentiments were echoed on Monday by Dana Loesch, who sued Breitbart\xe2\x80\x94citing an \xe2\x80\x9cincreasingly hostile\xe2\x80\x9d work environment\xe2\x80\x94before joining The Blaze, during her live show. \xe2\x80\x9cSteve Bannon puts himself above everything,\xe2\x80\x9d she said of her former boss. \xe2\x80\x9cI just don\xe2\x80\x99t think this is a good fit for the country. Maybe it is for Steve Bannon, but it\xe2\x80\x99s not a good fit for the country.\xe2\x80\x9d Loesch suggested that Bannon will enter the White House with \xe2\x80\x9cvengeance\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cpettiness\xe2\x80\x9d in his heart, which should alone \xe2\x80\x9cdisqualify\xe2\x80\x9d him from advising the president.

When Beck first joked that Bannon was angling to be Trump\xe2\x80\x99s chief of staff earlier this year, he had no idea how right he would end up being. That job may have ended up going to Reince Priebus, but it was Bannon who got top billing on the official press release. In the end, Bannon\xe2\x80\x99s ambitions far exceeded being the next Roger Ailes.

Now, a man who has never hid his disgust for Beck is about to become arguably the second most powerful person in Washington, if not the country. And at the same time, Trump and his team have made every indication that they intend to act hostilely toward a \xe2\x80\x9crigged\xe2\x80\x9d media that they believe has been biased against them from the beginning.

It is yet another irony that Beck now finds himself in their crosshairs along with the rest of us."
Description: b'The Blaze founder has become an unlikely voice of reason on the right. But what\xe2\x80\x99s really behind his grudge with Donald Trump\xe2\x80\x99s new chief strategist?'

Title: b"BREAKING: Top Trump Adviser Drops Bombshell... Wednesday Is the END of Hillary's Campaign"
Text:
b'One of Donald Trump\xe2\x80\x99s top surrogates made news when he intimated that a WikiLeaks release of information on Hillary Clinton, which he says will happen Wednesday, could finish her campaign.

In a Twitter posting this weekend, Trump adviser and Republican political consultant Roger Stone said that the information, which he says will be released Wednesday, will somehow end Hillary Clinton\xe2\x80\x99s campaign.

\xe2\x80\x9cWednesday @Hillary Clinton is done. #Wikileaks,\xe2\x80\x9d Stone tweeted.

TRENDING: How Trump Brilliantly Screwed Over Red State Dem Senators with Kavanaugh Nomination

Those security concerns are hardly illusory, especially when one is dealing with the left. Back in 2010, when WikiLeaks published a huge trove of classified diplomatic cables that embarrassed the Obama administration and then-Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, liberal commentator Bob Beckel recommended that Assange be assassinated, suggesting during a Fox News television appearance that someone \xe2\x80\x9cshoot the son of a bitch!\xe2\x80\x9d

Assange also intimated after his organization\xe2\x80\x99s leak of Democratic National Committee documents that murdered DNC staffer Seth Rich had been one of the organization\xe2\x80\x99s sources. According to The Hill, that hasn\xe2\x80\x99t stopped the organization, which has said it plans to release more information on Clinton before the Nov. 8 election.

It is unknown whether the delayed information will actually be released on Wednesday, but Stone seems to believe, from his tweet, that it will be.

WikiLeaks\xe2\x80\x99 most significant information dump on the Democrats, which occurred right before the Democratic National Convention in July, confirmed that the party organization was operating as a de facto arm of the Hillary Clinton campaign and was actively working to undermine the insurgent campaign of socialist Sen. Bernie Sanders.

The emails also exposed coordination between the DNC and the media.

How much more damaging are these emails than those that WikiLeaks has already released? If Roger Stone is right, this could be the biggest information dump in the organization\xe2\x80\x99s history. Stay tuned.

Title: b'Samsung raided in Park corruption probe'
Text:
b'Image copyright Reuters Image caption Ms Park has seen her approval ratings plummet amid the scandal

South Korean authorities have raided the offices of Samsung and the national pension fund as part of a corruption investigation linked to the president.

They are probing whether Park Geun-hye pressured the fund to support a Samsung merger, said the Yonhap news agency.

In return, Samsung is alleged to have given financial favours to Ms Park's confidante Choi Soon-sil, Yonhap said.

The scandal has led to growing calls for Ms Park's resignation, but she has said the allegations are "fantasy".

Ms Choi, who has been charged with coercion and attempted fraud, is accused of using her close relationship with Ms Park to obtain favours and funds for her own gain.

Earlier this week prosecutors said Ms Park had a "considerable" role in the scandal.

The allegations have enraged the South Korean public, and caused Ms Park's approval ratings to plummet. However, she has resisted the calls for her to resign and has yet to agree to be questioned by investigators.

Her spokesman rejected the prosecutors' case as speculation built on "a house of fantasy".

Image copyright EPA Image caption South Koreans have staged demonstrations calling for Ms Park's resignation

Samsung's offices had already been raided over related allegations.

Wednesday's raid had to do with a merger last year between the electronics giant's construction arm, Samsung C&T, and an affiliate firm, Cheil Industries.

The deal went through despite significant opposition from shareholders, who said it would hurt minority shareholders while benefiting the family of Samsung's group owner Lee Kun-hee.

South Korea's National Pension Service (NPS), which owns stakes in both companies, sealed the deal by voting in favour of it.

Prosecutors allege that Samsung gave \xe2\x82\xac2.8m euros ($3.1m;\xc2\xa32.5m) to a company co-owned by Ms Choi and her daughter, in return for Ms Park's support for the deal.

Samsung was also among several conglomerates that gave millions of dollars to two non-profit foundations owned by Ms Choi, after the latter allegedly pressured them for donations.

Samsung and the pension fund confirmed the raids without giving further details.

Image copyright AFP/Getty Images Image caption At the centre of the probe is Choi Soon-sil, a close confidante of Park Geun-hye

Ms Park is accused of giving Ms Choi inappropriate access to government policy-making and decisions.

She has since acknowledged that she committed lapses, and apologised twice on national television.

Separately on Wednesday, Ms Park's office confirmed a report that they had bought hundreds of Viagra pills on behalf of the president.

A spokesman told reporters that the drug, better known for treating erectile dysfunction among men, was meant to help Ms Park and her staff cope with high-altitude sickness during trips to Africa.'

But now I\xe2\x80\x99m highly offended. Trumps\xe2\x80\x99 wreath laying ceremony at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier today made my skin crawl. I come from a military family. My father was a veteran, I couldn\xe2\x80\x99t stop sobbing when they gave me the flag that draped his casket at Lincoln National cemetery. I have an uncle who died in a jeep accident in Germany on active duty, and a great uncle who lies at rest somewhere in the USS Arizona at Pearl Harbor, I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen his name on the wall of the memorial. I lost two close friends who were coworkers in Afghanistan, I attended both of the funerals. Even though I\xe2\x80\x99ll be 60 next month, I still carry my Vietnam era draft card in my wallet. This is personal to me.

It turned my stomach to watch that fat, arrogant orange penguin, who has sacrificed nothing and no one in his life, and who has so little respect for our brave troops that he referred to his swinging lifestyle in New York in the \xe2\x80\x9870s as his own personal Vietnam, even though he received phony deferments to keep from going to Vietnam, wrapping his tiny fingers around that wreath and placing it in front of the tomb of brave, anonymous men who sacrificed everything so that he could grab women by the crotch with impunity. But what really made my blood boil was when a commentator said that the next time he does that at Arlington, he\xe2\x80\x99ll be saluting instead of putting his hand over his heart! Needless to say, I won\xe2\x80\x99t be watching any of those future ceremonies for the next four years.

You all know that I have dug into Mein Furor pretty extensively for the last almost 20 months, and usually I just roll with the punches, by trying to heap scorn and sarcasm about everything he says or does. There is so much to hate about him that this website would have to expand to take the diaries if they were all to be chronicled. But these next four years are going to be rough for me, watching him pudge waddle down the steps of Marine One and throwing a salute to the guard soldier at the bottom of the steps, a man who would fight and die for him if Trump ordered it, and a man that Donald J. Trump couldn\xe2\x80\x99t give a shit less about.

Sorry for the rant, but this has been eating at me for almost three hours now, and I just had to get it out. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what I\xe2\x80\x99ll write about tomorrow, I had thought about not even turning on the t.v., but somehow I\xe2\x80\x99m sure I will, for no better reason than to find something to mock. Thanks to all who read for putting up with this rant!'

Title: b"Eight people 'as rich as poorest half'"
Text:
b'Image copyright Getty Images Image caption Superyachts are the calling card of some ultra-wealthy individuals

The world's eight richest individuals have as much wealth as the 3.6bn people who make up the poorest half of the world, according to Oxfam.

The charity said its figures, which critics have queried, came from improved data, and the gap between rich and poor was "far greater than feared".

The richest eight include Bill Gates, Mark Zuckerberg and Warren Buffett.

Mark Littlewood, of the Institute of Economic Affairs, said Oxfam should focus instead on ways to boost growth.

"As an 'anti-poverty' charity, Oxfam seems to be strangely preoccupied with the rich," said the director-general of the free market think tank.

For those concerned with "eradicating absolute poverty completely", the focus should be on measures that encourage economic growth, he added.

Ben Southwood, head of research at the Adam Smith Institute, said it was not the wealth of the world's rich that mattered, but the welfare of the world's poor, which was improving every year.

"Each year we are misled by Oxfam's wealth statistics. The data is fine - it comes from Credit Suisse - but the interpretation is not."

Media playback is unsupported on your device Media caption Economist Amartya Sen tells Radio 4's Today that economic inequality must be tackled

'Elite gathering'

Oxfam's report coincides with the start of the World Economic Forum in Davos, a Swiss ski resort. The annual event attracts many of the world's top political and business leaders.

Katy Wright, Oxfam's head of global external affairs, said the report helped the charity to "challenge the political and economic elites".

"We're under no illusions that Davos is anything other than a talking shop for the world's elite, but we try and use that focus," she added.

The world's eight richest billionaires

1. Bill Gates (US): co-founder of Microsoft (net worth $75bn)

2. Amancio Ortega (Spain): founder of Zara owner Inditex (net worth $67bn)

3. Warren Buffett (US): largest shareholder in Berkshire Hathaway (net worth $60.8bn)

4. Carlos Slim Helu (Mexico): owner of Grupo Carso (net worth $50bn)

5. Jeff Bezos (US): founder and chief executive of Amazon (net worth $45.2bn)

6. Mark Zuckerberg (US): co-founder and chief executive of Facebook (net worth $44.6bn)

7. Larry Ellison (US): co-founder and chief executive of Oracle (net worth $43.6bn)

8. Michael Bloomberg (US): owner of Bloomberg LP (net worth $40bn)

Source: Forbes billionaires' list, March 2016

UK economist Gerard Lyons said focusing on extreme wealth "does not always give the full picture" and attention should be paid to "making sure the economic cake is getting bigger".

However, he said Oxfam was right to single out companies that it believed fuelled inequality with business models that were "increasingly focused on delivering ever-higher returns to wealthy owners and top executives".

Oxfam's Ms Wright said economic inequality was fuelling a polarisation in politics, citing Donald Trump's election as US president and the Brexit vote as examples.

'Fair share'

"People are angry and calling out for alternatives. They're feeling left behind because however hard they work they can't share in their country's growth," she said.

The charity is calling for "a more human economy" and is urging governments to crack down on executive pay and tax evasion and impose higher taxes on the wealthy.

It also wants business leaders to pay a "fair share of tax" and has urged companies to pay staff the "living wage", which is higher than the government's National Living Wage.

Oxfam has produced similar reports for the past four years. In 2016 it calculated that the richest 62 people in the world had as much wealth as the poorest half of the global population.

The number had fallen to just eight this year because more accurate data was now available, Oxfam said.

It was still the case that the world's richest 1% had as much wealth as the rest of the world combined, Oxfam said.

Image copyright Getty Images Image caption Facebook co-founder Mark Zuckerberg and wife Priscilla Chan

Some of the eight richest billionaires have given away tens of billions of dollars. In 2000 Bill Gates and his wife Melinda set up a private foundation that has an endowment of more than $44bn.

In 2015 Mark Zuckerberg and his wife Priscilla Chan pledged to give away 99% of their net worth in their lifetimes, which equated to about $45bn based on the value of Facebook shares at the time.

It takes cash and assets worth $71,600 to get into the top 10%, and $744,396 to be in the top 1%.

Oxfam's report is based on data from Forbes and the annual Credit Suisse Global Wealth datebook, which gives the distribution of global wealth going back to 2000.

The survey uses the value of an individual's assets, mainly property and land, minus debts, to determine what he or she "owns". The data excludes wages or income.

The methodology has been criticised as it means that a student with high debts, but with high future earning potential, for example, would be considered poor under the criteria used.'

Title: b'Rob Lowe says players who boycott national anthem on 9/11 should stay in locker room'
Text:
b"Colin Kaepernick\xe2\x80\x99s protest against the national anthem has sparked an ongoing debate about the obligation of players to stand \xe2\x80\x94 or not stand \xe2\x80\x94 during the anthem.

Many players have joined with Kaepernick\xe2\x80\x99s protest in solidarity, but with the first Sunday of NFL season falling on the anniversary of the September 11th attacks, many think it would be inappropriate for players to not stand on such a sad day.

Rob Lowe is one of them, and on Saturday, he tweeted saying that the NFL should ask players to stay in the locker room rather than publicly protest the anthem.

Dear @NFL Any player wants to boycott the anthem on 9/11 should be asked to remain in the locker room until kick off. It's not their moment. \xe2\x80\x94 Rob Lowe (@RobLowe) September 11, 2016

Title: b'\xe2\x80\x98Hard to get inside Mosul, over 1mn people still trapped amid op\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x93 Oxfam representative to RT'
Text:
b'Humanitarian organizations face serious difficulties in delivering aid to people inside Iraq\xe2\x80\x99s Mosul amid the US-backed operation against Islamic State, Oxfam spokesman who returned from Iraq told RT. Over 1 million people are still trapped in the city.

"Unfortunately, it\xe2\x80\x99s very difficult for humanitarian agencies like Oxfam to get into Mosul itself," Kai Tabacek, Oxfam's digital press officer said in an interview to RT. He returned just a month ago from the area of Irbil, which is 90 kilometers from Mosul.

Read more

According to Tabacek, some 100,000 people have managed to flee the violence in Mosul, yet approximately 10 times more are still in the city and facing a \xe2\x80\x9cdire humanitarian situation.\xe2\x80\x9d



After almost two months of operation to liberate Mosul \xe2\x80\x9cwe have more than 100,000 people who have fled the city and surrounding areas,\xe2\x80\x9d the Oxfam representative said. \xe2\x80\x9cStill more than a million people, we believe, are trapped inside Mosul and they are at risk from being caught by sniper fire, explosive devices. And it's really important that all sides in this conflict provide safe escape routes for those people to leave.\xe2\x80\x9d



Mosul was captured by Islamic State (IS, formerly ISIS/ISIL) back in 2014 and later turned into a self-proclaimed capital of the jihadists in Iraq. The operation to retake the key city started on October 17, with tens of thousands of Iraqi military, special forces and militias taking part. The mission is also supported by the US-led international coalition.

\xe2\x80\x9cThe situation is not great, particularly with winter arriving in Iraq,\xe2\x80\x9d Tabacek said. Yet \xe2\x80\x9cso far most of the displaced families leaving Mosul have been able to access some form of assistance from Oxfam and from others [humanitarian organizations]."

Read more

The Oxfam press officer also noted that it\xe2\x80\x99s crucial for all sides to avoid using heavy weaponry inside the city since it puts civilian lives at risk.



\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s very worrying when there is a conflict that close to where the people are living and we\xe2\x80\x99ve seen in other places and in Mosul so far, the way ISIS seem willing to use people as human shields,\xe2\x80\x9d Tabacek warned.



He also said that liberating Mosul won\xe2\x80\x99t automatically eliminate the humanitarian crisis in the area: \xe2\x80\x9cMore than 3 million people that are displaced in northern Iraq. And that\xe2\x80\x99s not only from Mosul, that's a number of other areas that have been recaptured in the last few years. This is a crisis that is not going to go away anytime soon,\xe2\x80\x9d Tabacek said.



Meanwhile, the operation to retake Mosul has slowed down in the past weeks since the Iraqi army and militias are going deeper into the city. In addition, an early December report by Debkafiles, a military intelligence news site with links to the Israeli military, said Islamic State is now mulling to stay put in their Iraqi stronghold. According to the report, a delegation of IS commanders arrived in Mosul on December 4, to discuss synchronizing the city defenses with those of Raqqa in Syria. Mosul commanders have \xe2\x80\x9cchanged course about leaving the city and decided to stay put,\xe2\x80\x9d the paper said.

Title: b'WATCH: Bill Maher HAMMERS Trump In Final Plea To Voters On Fallon'
Text:
b'Bill Maher made an appearance on The Tonight Show with Jimmy Fallon and made sure everyone knows exactly who Donald trump is and why we shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t vote for him.

Fallon asked for Maher\xe2\x80\x99s thoughts on the election and he did not disappoint. Maher conceded that Hillary is not the best candidate, but said she will be a good president.

He then slammed Trump for cheering for Russian hackers to keep committing espionage against the United States.

\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s not funny,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cThis is a different thing.\xe2\x80\x9d

\xe2\x80\x9cI did a whole mea culpa on my show Friday night, I talked about Mitt Romney, George Bush, Reagan, McCain like it was the end of the world. It would never have been the end of the world with those guys. This is different. This guy is different. They have no respect for the rule of law. It\xe2\x80\x99s only about vengeance.\xe2\x80\x9d

When asked what he would say to undecided voters, Maher made things simple.

\xe2\x80\x9cFirst of all, really? I mean, he\xe2\x80\x99s a racist, a liar, a tax cheat, a deadbeat, a Russian agent, and a sexual predator. \xe2\x80\x98How do you find your way out of the door in the morning?\xe2\x80\x99 is what I would say to the undecideds.\xe2\x80\x9d

Maher concluded by slamming conservatives for creating an alternate reality where America is failing and President Obama did a horrible jobs. The facts, however, paint a different story before unemployment is down to 4.9 percent and the stock market has more than recovered since the Great Recession.

Americans need to vote in this election no matter what. The future of this nation depends on it.

Title: b'Restoring Free Speech: The Trump Effect'
Text:

Restoring Free Speech: The Trump Effect

Years ago, Rush Limbaugh coined the term, \xe2\x80\x9cLow-info Voters.\xe2\x80\x9d The term perfectly describes Americans, like 95% of my family, who only get their news from the mainstream media. Consequently, low-info voters do not know that the mainstream media is not fair and balanced. The mainstream media has become strong-arm enforcers of political correctness and operatives of the Democrat Party; 100% focused and committed to furthering the socialist/progressive agenda. Yes, I remember when I was a kid my black Baltimore City firefighter dad told me, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Republicans are for the rich and the Democrats are for the little guy; the working man.\xe2\x80\x9d

A few years ago, I was able to convince my 89-year-old dad that this \xe2\x80\x9cain\xe2\x80\x99t\xe2\x80\x9d his Democrat Party of his youth. Dad\xe2\x80\x99s Democrat Party has been hijacked by old hippies. They reject Christianity while vowing to arrest anyone speaking badly of Islam. They use public schools to teach our kids to despise all things traditional, wholesome, patriotic and good. They are the ones who have, for the most part, made it criminal to publicly say you believe marriage should remain as it has been for thousands of years and how God intended; between one man and one woman (Genesis 2:24). They are the ones banning Nativity scenes and banning saying \xe2\x80\x9cMerry Christmas.\xe2\x80\x9d They are the ones banning teachers addressing students as boys and girls, claiming gender distinctions are intolerant, discriminatory and bigoted. They are the ones pushing the extinction of blacks via a disproportionate high number of black abortions. This it why it continues to frost me when low-info idiots in my black \xe2\x80\x9cChristian\xe2\x80\x9d family continue to pledge their brain-dead loyalty to Democrats while calling me their Uncle Tom relative. The Left uses a highly effective tactic. They brand any push-back to them cramming their progressive agenda down our throats \xe2\x80\x9cextremism.\xe2\x80\x9d This tactic works great with so many low-info voters.

Here is how it works. The Left says they want burly men with beards, dressed like lumberjacks to be permitted to use women restrooms if they inwardly feel like a woman that day. Husbands, fathers and brothers across America politically said, No-way. We are not allowing grown men in restrooms with our little girls, wives and mothers. Government mandating this insane restroom policy and Leftist businesses like Target embracing it has led to rapes and molestation in women restrooms. And yet, guess who the mainstream media and Democrats attack, calling them extremist? Answer: All who oppose men in women restrooms. In an attempt to demonize and silence American\xe2\x80\x99s common-sense disagreement, the Left claims anyone opposing men in women restrooms hates homosexuals and want to see them tortured and murdered. If you oppose the Left removing crosses from memorials, removing the Ten Commandments from public buildings, banning Nativity scenes and banning saying \xe2\x80\x9cMerry Christmas\xe2\x80\x9d, the Left claims you\xe2\x80\x99re an extremist who hates homosexuals, suppresses women and want to cram your religion down everyone\xe2\x80\x99s throat. Do you see how the Left\xe2\x80\x99s extremism tactic works? b'We are sorely in need of some cheerful news out of Washington, so I\xe2\x80\x99m going to tell you Barbara Mikulski\xe2\x80\x99s story about the Senate bathrooms.

Almost every veteran woman legislator, in every level of government, has a story about the shortage of bathroom facilities at work. Really, there needs to be a book on this. It could have a happy ending, and none of the chapters would involve Russian attempts to manipulate an election.

Mikulski, 80, has served in Congress longer than any other woman in history. She\xe2\x80\x99s retiring this month after representing Maryland for 30 years in the Senate. Before that she spent 10 years in the House. She was a social worker who got into Democratic politics during a battle to stop a planned highway that was threatening the ethnic Baltimore neighborhoods she loved. It was an unusual career route at the time, but she was an unusual person. \xe2\x80\x9cOne of the things they said was that I didn\xe2\x80\x99t look the part,\xe2\x80\x9d Mikulski, who is 4-foot-11, recalled. \xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\xa6 You know, chunky and I have a definite blue-collar style, so I wasn\xe2\x80\x99t to the manner born, to the trust fund inherited.\xe2\x80\x9d

The classic way for a woman to win a seat in the Senate was to follow a famous male relative. Many of her predecessors were widows who succeeded their husbands. Nancy Kassebaum, the only other woman in the Senate when Mikulski arrived, was the daughter of the Republican presidential candidate Alf Landon.'

Title: b'The Every Student Succeeds Act will Fail - The Boston Globe'
Text:
b'Across the country, schools and school districts have begun to implement the Every Student Succeeds Act of 2015. The law is the latest reauthorization of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act, first passed in 1965. Yet, despite the fanfare and promise to usher in a new era, this newest version \xe2\x80\x94 like so many federal and state schemes to implement high standards for student learning \xe2\x80\x94 will fail. The regulatory process associated with implementation will inevitably corrupt the law\xe2\x80\x99s intent.

I have witnessed this again and again in my 35 years as a teacher \xe2\x80\x94 a front-row seat from which I have viewed the deadening impact on schools and classrooms of standards as regulatory tools. At the same time, however, I have also been inspired by the inventive ways that school-level educators and communities have used similar standards to foster powerful learning.

In 1989, I joined a circle of colleagues and parents frustrated by the focus on testing of the well-regarded high school in our suburban community near Albany, N.Y. At the time, New York State\xe2\x80\x99s curriculum consisted of thick manuals with long lists of learning objectives and a battery of tests, the vaunted Regents Exams. Our small group asked: How can we engage students in learning more fully beyond a narrow desire to ace the exam?

Advertisement

Over the course of several years we designed and launched an alternative school-within-a-school, in which tests took a back seat to projects designed to simulate real world problems. Each semester, students in the Bethlehem Lab School presented their work before a panel of adults drawn from the community. The high stakes of a juried exhibition pushed our students to focus, and the complex nature of the work forced them to think more deeply and broadly than they were accustomed.

Our students didn\xe2\x80\x99t take Regents Exams. At the time, students in New York State could opt for a \xe2\x80\x9clocal\xe2\x80\x9d diploma instead. We chose this lower status designation as an entire school to free ourselves to create a more demanding curriculum, based on New York State\xe2\x80\x99s own learning standards. It turned out that at the back of all those thick curriculum books put out by the state stood an elegantly simple list of 10 goals. It fit on one page. It was our constitution. And though the Regents curriculum was, theoretically, based on the 10 goals, the process of parsing out learning objectives in each subject and the demands of psychometricians for reliability and validity resulted in a curriculum overweight with content, instruction focused on memorization, and tests that rewarded students able to retain lots and lots of information. The system demanded compliance more than it fostered learning.

Several years later, I was invited to join a new public charter school in Massachusetts as principal teacher. The Francis W. Parker Charter Essential School was founded by parents and educators who pioneered an approach to standards and assessment in which each student continuously created original work assembled into a portfolio. Revision was encouraged, and standards were printed on posters hung on the walls of every classroom. Students worked hard to improve their essays, lab reports, and projects until they met the standards, and when they demonstrated to their teachers and classmates through a live exhibition that the standards were met, they were promoted.

Those were heady times in Massachusetts. The Education Reform Act of 1993 that enabled charter schools also promised a statewide assessment system to include portfolios and other forms of \xe2\x80\x9cauthentic\xe2\x80\x9d assessment like those at the Lab School and the Parker School. But first, under political pressure, regulators were compelled to generate thick manuals of finely parsed learning objectives. Then, the psychometricians went to work figuring out how to measure learning. Shortly, the Department of Education rolled out a battery of on-demand tests, with the grandiose title of the Massachusetts Comprehensive Assessment System, or what we know today more often as the MCAS. No portfolios and nothing authentic about them. Again, compliance ruled the day. Teachers and students would have to fall in line.

2001 saw passage of the No Child Left Behind Act. Standards as regulatory tool, in force in some states, became the law of the land. They called it accountability.

Advertisement

In 2006, after 25 years in schools, I reinvented myself as an assistant professor at a nearby university. I wanted to know: Were my experiences part of a larger pattern? I quickly learned two things. The first is that there is a boatload of research showing that accountability has narrowed the curriculum nationwide and turned schools serving our nation\xe2\x80\x99s neediest students into test prep factories. And the second is legions of education researchers have seized on the rising tide of test data to answer their questions. The answers are often simplistic in ways that belie the complexity of schools and classrooms, while legitimizing the testing culture.

As evidence has mounted that the accountability regime is turning many schools into test prep centers, advocates for accountability have argued that schools need not slavishly teach to the test. Instead, they say, schools should offer a robust curriculum with demanding instruction, and the tests will take care of themselves. This sounds like common sense, but in a study I just completed with Megin Charner-Laird of Salem State University and Stacy Szczesiul of the University of Massachusetts Lowell, we found that schools with reliably high test scores \xe2\x80\x94 while not teaching to the test per se \xe2\x80\x94 tend to teach a limited range of skills required for the test. Teachers and administrators told us they would aspire to something more, but this is what the system demands.

At schools like the Lab School and the Parker School, demanding standards, attached to assessments that rely on judgment, foster powerful learning. At the system level, strict reliance on measurement, where judgment is expunged as a contaminant, has served to narrow learning and diminish student engagement.

The Every Student Succeeds Act, or ESSA as it is known, holds on to this fundamental element of the accountability movement like a dog does a bone. Meanwhile, a Gallup Student Poll administered last fall shows 68 percent of high school juniors unengaged in school. Portfolios, juried exhibitions, external audits, peer review \xe2\x80\x94 all of which rely on judgment informed with evidence \xe2\x80\x94 have been marginalized at the system level, but they are exactly what works at the local level in pushing students to think deeply and engage in learning. Perhaps after ESSA fails to deliver, we will get the message, and a new policy regime will be driven not by the question how do we measure X, but, instead, how do we engage and inspire children and youth?

James Nehring is a former Fulbright Scholar and an associate professor of education at the University of Massachusetts Lowell. He is the author, most recently, of \xe2\x80\x9cWhy Teach? Notes and Questions from a Life in Education.\xe2\x80\x9d'
